title: 31.2 Greatest Common Divisor
content:
Section 31.2

Greatest Common Divisor

Summary

Euclid's algorithm for computing gcd efficiently.

Key Points

  • Euclid: gcd(a,b) = gcd(b, a mod b)
  • Base case: gcd(a, 0) = a
  • Time: O(log min(a,b)) - very fast!
  • Extended Euclid: find x,y such that ax + by = gcd(a,b)
  • Useful for modular inverse: a⁻¹ mod n

Pseudocode

EXTENDED-EUCLID(a, b):
    if b == 0:
        return (a, 1, 0)
    (d, x', y') = EXTENDED-EUCLID(b, a mod b)
    return (d, y', x' - ⌊a/b⌋·y')

Example

gcd(99, 78): 99 = 1·78 + 21, 78 = 3·21 + 15, 21 = 1·15 + 6, 15 = 2·6 + 3, 6 = 2·3 + 0. gcd = 3.

Why It Matters

Euclid's algorithm is 2300+ years old and still optimal!
